title: Speak in Real Life Today! — Confidence Practice Lab
objectives: Build the courage to speak English in real-world situations
Learn polite, practical phrases for daily interactions
Embrace small mistakes and keep the conversation going
Bridge the gap from practice-mode to real-life usage

activities.text: Welcome to Lesson 12: “Speak in Real Life Today!” This is our Confidence Practice Lab. You’ve learned basic phrases and grammar—now it’s time to use them outside in the real world! थोड़ा Hindi mix and lots of English for real action.

activities.title: Why This Lesson Is Important
activities.body: Many learners freeze when they face real conversations. Don’t worry—mistakes are normal. Focus on delivering your message. Mixing Hindi is okay too. The goal here? Jump from practice → real-life action!

activities.question: What’s your biggest fear in REAL English conversations?
options: I mix Hindi & English, feel awkward

dynamicFeedback.0: Try 1-2 short phrases you remember—don’t panic!
dynamicFeedback.1: Politely ask them to slow down: “Could you speak slower, please?”
dynamicFeedback.2: It’s okay! Hinglish is a stepping stone, keep speaking!

activities.text: Mistakes mean you tried—congratulations! आप 100 times आगे हो than someone who stays silent. Today, we’ll see 5 real-life practice zones with short phrases. Jump in, make small talk, and improve!

activities.title: 5 Real-Life Practice Zones
activities.body:
1) At a Shop
2) With a Family Member
3) At a Tea Stall / Café
4) With a Stranger (park)
5) On a Phone Call

Use short phrases, polite tone, and smile. We’ll give you templates, then you try in real life!

activities.text: Let’s begin with Zone 1: At a Shop. You’ll ask price, greet, and end politely. Remember: “Hello, how much is this?” Simple line, big impact!

vocabItems.meaning: Used for polite address: “Excuse me, Sir?”
When asking price: “How much is this, please?”
Adds politeness: “Could you pack it, please?”
Close on a polite note: “Thank you for your help!”

scenes.mentorTip: Sound confident: ‘Hello, how much is this, please?’

scenes.userLine: Okay, I’ll take it. Can you pack it?
scenes.mentorTip: Remember to say ‘please’: ‘Can you pack it, please?’

activities.prompt: Try saying out loud: “Excuse me, Sir, how much is this?”

activities.text: Next, Zone 2: Talk with a Family Member in English, even if it’s for 2 lines. It might feel strange, but it helps you warm up! Example: “Mom, I’m going out for a walk,” or “Papa, I finished my homework.”

scenes.text:
**Scenario: With a Family Member**

You: “Mom, I’m heading out to meet a friend. I’ll be back by 7 PM.”
Mom: “Alright, take care.”
You: “Sure. Do you need anything from the shop?”
Mom: “No, I’m good. Thank you!”

**Key Learning**: Small daily lines in English—totally fine to mix some Hindi if stuck!

activities.prompt: Practice: ‘Mom, I’m going out for a walk. I’ll be back by ___ PM.’

activities.text: Zone 3: At a Tea Stall or Café. Order politely, say ‘please’ and ‘thank you.’ Even short lines like ‘Bhaiya, ek chai dena’ can become ‘Could I have one tea, please?’

scenes.userLine: Hi, can I get a cup of tea, please?

activities.text: Zone 4: With a Stranger (like in a park). You can start by asking the time, or directions. Be polite and brief. Example: “Excuse me, do you know what time it is?”

scenes.text:
**Scenario: Stranger in a Park**

You: “Excuse me, could you tell me how far the main gate is?”
Stranger: “It’s about 200 meters ahead.”
You: “Great, thanks! Also, do you know what time it is?”
Stranger: “It’s 5:30 PM.”

**Key Learning**: Keep it short and simple, always add a ‘thank you’ or ‘thanks!’

vocabItems.meaning: Use before asking: 'Excuse me, could you help?'
'Could you tell me how far the gate is?' Polite phrase for directions.
Extra polite: 'Thank you so much for your help!'

activities.prompt: Practice: ‘Excuse me, do you know what time it is?’

activities.text: Zone 5: On a Phone Call—call a friend or family member and try 2-3 lines in English. Basic steps: Greet, ask a question, end politely. You got this!

scenes.userLine: Hey, how are you? Are you busy right now?
scenes.mentorLine: I’m good! No, I’m free—tell me?

scenes.userLine: I just wanted to ask if you’re free this weekend.
scenes.mentorTip: Invite them or ask a quick question!

activities.title: If You Get Stuck
activities.body:
1) Pause and smile
2) Use Hindi if needed, then switch back
3) Ask them to repeat: “I’m sorry, could you say that again?”
4) End with positivity: “Thank you for understanding!”

clips.label: Broken: Fearful Tone
clips.transcript: “Uh… Hello… how… how much… is… this?”

activities.question: Hearing these clips, what do you think is the main difference?

dynamicFeedback.0: Yes! Tone and clarity matter more than perfect grammar.
dynamicFeedback.1: Grammar helps, but tone & confidence are bigger factors.
dynamicFeedback.2: Pitch can help, but it’s not the main difference.
dynamicFeedback.3: Focus on short lines, confident tone!

activities.title: Emotional Support
activities.body:
Mistake? Great job, you tried!
You’re 100x ahead of someone silent.
One English word a day keeps fear away.
Keep going—you’re unstoppable!

activities.text: If you try these 5 zones in real life—even 1 short conversation daily—you’ll see fast improvement. Don’t wait for perfection, jump in and speak!

activities.title: Mini-Homework
activities.body: Today, pick 1 Zone (shop/family/tea stall/stranger/phone call) and use at least 2 lines of English. That’s all—just do it, no overthinking!

activities.title: Real-Life Speaker
activities.description: Congratulations! You’ve unlocked confidence to speak in real-life English scenarios. Celebrate your small steps—they lead to big success!
